Travel all over the Holy Land for a tiny fraction of the cost

With The Octagon Project you will feel like you are actually walking through Israel, being totally immersed in all of the sights and sounds of the Holy Land. Our specially-formatted videos play on any computer, any mobile device, and all virtual reality headsets.

We will take you to every location in the nation of Israel and Jordan that is named in the Gospels...and more! The Octagon Project is the equivalent of an expertly-guided VIP 30-day tour to the Holy Land. You will walk in places where most tourists don\'t have time to visit, or are never allowed to go.

There are 30 tours in The Octagon Project. With your free membership you will able to view a 360-degree intro video of each tour at no cost. Then when you are ready, purchase only the full tours that you want to go on. Just click the Free Signup button below.
Tour #2 is now ready for purchase! Preview this tour here.

Unlike an actual "live" tour to the Holy Land, The Octagon Project has the capability of escorting you through the entire land in the chronological order of The Merged Gospels. There are 30 tours in The Octagon Project. In every tour there will be a free introductory video, which you can access by becoming a "lite" subscriber. All of the other videos on each tour require that you purchase that particular tour. When you purchase any tour, you will be able to watch all the 360° videos on your computer and mobile devices, and in virtual reality with any smartphone or VR headgear.
There are two ways to get on board.
Opening an account will allow you to view all of the introductory videos for each of our 30 tours for free.
When you purchase any tour, you will be able to watch all the 360° videos on your computer and mobile devices, and in stereoscopic virtual reality with any smartphone or VR headgear.

Tour 1 - The Prologue To The Gospel
During this primer you will be introduced to many of the sites of Israel, and you will receive a complete overview of the entire 30-day Octagon Project tour.
Available now. Introductory price-$4.99. 13 videos. 2.25 hours

Sites visited – The Church of St. Anne (the birthplace of Mary), The Church of the Annunciation, The Dome of the Rock and Cave of Souls, The Church St. Gabriel (the annunciation site), John the Baptist’s Cave, The Church of John the Baptist in Ein Karem (John’s birthplace), Mary’s Spring (Ein Karem), Mary’s Well (Nazareth) and The Temple Mount.

Sites visited – Herod’s Grand Palace, the Jerusalem Model, the Church of St. Joseph, the Kathisma (where Mary rested), the Kishle (ruins of Herod’s palace), the International Mary of Nazareth Center, the Milk Grotto (Jesus’ infant home), the Chapel of the Holy Innocents, the Church of the Nativity, Nazareth Ruins, the Ophel Archeological Park, both the Franciscan and the YMCA Shepherd’s Field, the Monastery of Theodosius (the Magi Cave), the Tower of David Museum and the Church of the Visitation (of Mary to Elizabeth).

Sites visited – The Ophel Archeological Park, Elijah’s Hill (with John’s cave), En Gedi, the Church of St. John the Baptist in the Old City, the Church of Madaba (the Madaba map), Naharayim (baptism site), Qasr Al Yehud (baptism site), Qumran (the Dead Sea Scrolls), The Monastery of Temptation and Wadi Kharrar (John’s original baptism site in Jordan).
Sites visited – Bethsaida (original home of the first apostles), The Franciscan and Orthodox churches of Cana, Khirbet Kana (ruins of Cana) and Yardenit (baptism site).
Sites visited – Capernaum, the Gethsemane Grotto, Ainon near Salim (where John baptized, Tiberias, The Temple Mount and the Jerusalem Model.

Sites visited – Sychar (where Jesus stayed 3 days), Mount Gerazim (where the Samaritans still worship), Magdala (home of Mary Magdalene), the Maronite Cliff (where a crowd tried to kill Jesus), Megiddo, the Church of Saint Photini (the woman at the well), Mount Precipice and the Synagogue Church (Jesus’ childhood synagogue).

Sites visited – Capernaum, Peter’s home, the Capernaum synagogue, the Sea of Galilee, Gamla (where thousands of Jews ended their own lives, Hippos, Korazin (the town Jesus cursed) and the Valley of the Doves (the path of Jesus from Nazareth to Capernaum).
Tour 9 - The Sermon On The Mount

Sites visited – The traditional Church of the Beatitudes, the actual site of the Sermon on the Mount, the Eremos Cave (where Jesus prayed) and the Eremos Heights (where Jesus appointed His 12 Apostles).

Sites visited – A boat ride on the Sea of Galilee, Kursi (where Jesus cast the demons into the swine), Nain (where Jesus raised a widow’s son), the Bay of Parables, the Church of the 12 Apostles, Capernaum, the Temple Mount and Tiberias.
Sites visited – The Pool of Bethesda, Hezekiah’s Broad Wall, the St. Stephen’s Gate, Capernaum and the Jerusalem Model.

Sites visited – Sebastia (Samaria), the cliffs of Arbel (overlooking the Sea of Galilee), an ancient Genessaret boat dock, Har Menorim (the Feeding of the 5000), the Church of John the Baptist in Sebastia, the tomb of John the Baptist, Capernaum, Tiberias, Galilee and Bethsaida.

Sites visited – Caesarea Philipi, the Church of the Multiplication, Nimrod’s Fortress, Mount Tabor (the traditional site of the Transfiguration of Jesus), Tel Dan, Tel Hadar (possible site of the feeding of the 4000), Capernaum, Bethsaida and Magdala.
Sites visited – Ein Fawar (Jesus’ walking path to Jericho), the Monastery of St. George in Wadi Qelt, Capernaum, Sebastia and the Temple Mount.

Sites visited – Beit She’an (Israel’s largest archeological site), the Bethany crusader ruins, the Bethany Church of St. Lazarus, the Pater Noster Convent (where Jesus taught The Lord’s Prayer, and the Temple Mount.
Tour 16 - Jesus\' Confrontation with the Jews
Sites visited – The Bethany Orthodox Church (with the Seat of Jesus, the Canaanite Tunnel, Hezekiah’s drainage tunnel, Lazarus’ Tomb, the Temple Mount and the Jerusalem Model.
Tour 17 - Bethany and the city of David

Sites visited – The City of David, the covered Herodian street, David’s palace, the Pool of Siloam, the Theodotus Synagogue (the story of the Man born blind), the Tower of Siloam, Wadi Kharrar, the Temple Mount and Capernaum.
Tour 19 - The Final path of Jerusalem
Sites visited – Tiberias, the palace of Herod Antipas and the Temple Mount.
Sites visited – Burquin (the cave of the 10 Lepers), Zedekiah’s Cave, Mount Carmel, the Herodion, Herod’s Gate, the Jaffa Gate, the Dung Gate, the New Gate and Stella Maris (the cave of Elijah).
Tour 21 - The Jericho That Jesus Knew
Sites visited – The Judean Wilderness, both Herodian and Old Testament Jericho, they Sycamore Tree in Jericho, and Wadi Kharrar (the original baptism site of John).

Sites visited – Bethphage (where Jesus borrowed the donkey), Dominus Flevit (where Jesus wept), Palm Sunday Road from Bethany to Jerusalem, the Golden Gate on the eastern wall of the Temple Mount, the Temple Mount, the Jerusalem Model, and various sites in Bethany.
Sites visited – The Rabbinic tunnels under Jerusalem, the Western Wall and Wilson Arch Library, the Ophel Archeological Park, the Temple Mount, and the Jerusalem model.
Sites visited – The Cemetery on the Mount of Olives, the Tomb of the Prophets, and the Pater Noster Convent.

Sites visited – David’s Tomb, the Dormition Abbey (where Mary died), St. Peter in Gallicantu (the traditional home of Caiaphas), the Maccabean Stairs (where Jesus walked), the Upper Room (Cenacle), the Church of St. Mark (the alternative Upper Room), the Zion Gate and Oscar Schindlar’s grave.

Sites visited – The Garden of Gethsemane, the traditional home of the high priest Annas, the Church of All Nations (with the Stone of Agony), the Kidron Valley and tombs, Mary’s Tomb, the Gethsemane Grotto, and the Church of St. Peter in Gallicantu.

Sites visited – The Via Dolorosa (with all the Stations of the Cross), the Prison of Christ and Barabbas, the Lithostratos, the Church of St. James, the location of the Hasmonean Palace (Jesus’ trial with Herod), Gabbatha, the Kishle (ruins of Herod’s palace), the Courtyard of Flagellation, the Alexander Nevsky Compound (with the Judgment Gate), the Potter’s Field, the Temple Mount and the Jerusalem Model.

Sites visited – The Church of the Holy Sepulcher (including all chapels), the Garden Tomb, the Monastery of the Cross (from where the cross was cut), the Lutheran Church of the Redeemer, the Byzantine Model, the Jerusalem Model, and Herod Agrippa’s Third Wall.
Sites visited – Emmaus, the Church of Mary Magdalene, the Church of the Holy Sepulcher, the Mensa Christi Chapel in Nazareth, the Church of St. Mark, the Upper Room (Cenacle) and the Temple Mount.
Tour 30 - The Final Days Of Jesus

Sites visited – The Ascension Chapel, the Damascus Gate, the Cardo Maximus, Hadrian’s Forum, the Monastery of Mar Saba, Masada, the Church of Peter’s Primacy, the site of the Sermon on the Mount, the Ophel Archeological Park, and the Zion Gate.
Come To The Holyland On A Live Octagon Project Tour

An Octagon Tour is the only tour of it’s kind in the Holy Land, because we focus exclusively on the life of Jesus. Every site we take you to is referred to in the Gospels. (Check out our itinerary on this page, and you will see what we mean.) This means that you will be visiting all of the sites that you really came to see.

Every day we will put you in the three-foot circle of Jesus. You will walk where He walked, sit where He taught, and stand where He did His miracles. All of our guides are Christians, and our itinerary has been designed by Gary Crossland himself. The Merged Gospels is our field guide for our entire trip.

Most of our travelers who have been to Israel before with other tours tell us that ours is about 75% unique. The reason is simple – it’s ALL about Jesus.

Throughout 2016 we have focused our attention on launching The Octagon Project virtual tour. Very soon we will be restarting our Octagon Live Tours to Israel.

And what about safety? Don’t be misguided by the media. People are coming to Israel by the droves from all over the world. The fact is that at any moment the safest place to be in the Holy Land is on a tour bus. Since Israel became a sovereign state in 1948 literally no one who has been a part of a tour group has ever been injured or killed there. The reason? Tourists bring money, and everyone wants to sell you something, including the Palestinians. Hence, everyone likes tourists.
